Issues.Title: build: fix adev first party linking and re-enable tests
Issues.Body:
Follow-up to https://github.com/angular/angular/pull/55282

This commit attempts to finally fix the long-standing first-party package linking issue with the rather tricky `rules_nodejs` toolchain.

I've verified that no version of e.g. `@angular/core` ends up in the Bazel sandbox. This is achieved by also filtering transitive Angular deps for first-party linked packages. e.g. `@angular/docs`.

In addition, `@angular/docs` accidentally ended up bundling parts of Angular core because it relied on an entry-point that was not part of the "well known externals". As part of the ongoing `ng_package` update/rewrite, we should look into disabling bundling of ANY external dependency/module. This is possible because we use relative imports inside APF packages as of recently!

This commit should allow us to develop and continue new compiler features, without having to temporarily (or longer) disable all `angular.dev` unit tests!

Issues.Title: support `**` wildcard between path segments (e.g., `/foo/**/bar`)
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are relevant/related to the feature request?

_No response_

### Description


### Problem
Angular Router currently supports `**` only as a catch-all at the end of a route. It lacks support for multi-segment wildcards *between* fixed segments‚Äîe.g., `/foo/**/bar` should match `/foo/a/bar`, `/foo/a/b/c/bar`, but not `/foo/bar`.

The only workaround today is a custom `UrlMatcher`, which introduces unnecessary complexity, boilerplate, and testing burden for a common pattern.

### Proposal

### Component Access
Intermediate segments could be exposed via `ActivatedRoute`, e.g.:

```ts
const segments = route.snapshot.paramMap.get('wildcardSegments');
```
Allow `**` to be used between segments in the `path` property:

```ts
{ path: 'foo/**/bar', component: MyComponent }
```

Matching rules:
- Must start with `foo`, end with `bar`
- Must include one or more intermediate segments

Examples:
- ‚úÖ `/foo/a/bar`, `/foo/a/b/c/bar`
- ‚ùå `/foo/bar`, `/foo/a/b/baz`

### Benefits
- Declarative, readable routing for hierarchical paths
- Avoids verbose `UrlMatcher` implementations
- Improves DX, reduces boilerplate, aids tooling and static analysis

Related:
- https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/issues/29444
- https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/issues/29420
- https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/issues/29384

Issues.Body: The Angular compiler does not directly support the `composite` option within a referenced `tsconfig` file. Issues.Title: feat(dialog): Full-screen dialog
Issues.Body:
### Feature Description

#### Overview
This feature request proposes adding a full-screen display option to the existing Angular Material Dialog component. This enhancement would allow dialogs to expand to occupy the entire viewport, providing a more immersive experience for content-heavy dialogs while maintaining the existing Dialog API.

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/f0eea513-124c-4de1-af8d-6f20db23351d)

#### Problem Statement
The current Angular Material Dialog component is limited to fixed or responsive sizing within the viewport. While this works well for typical dialog use cases, there are scenarios where a full-screen dialog would provide a better user experience.

Developers currently work around this limitation by:
- Creating custom full-screen components outside the Dialog system
- Using CSS hacks to force dialogs to expand beyond their intended size
- Implementing non-standard patterns that break Material Design guidelines

These workarounds lead to inconsistent implementations, maintenance overhead, and potential accessibility issues.

#### Proposed Solution
Enhance the MatDialog service and related components to support a new `fullScreen` configuration option that, when enabled, renders the dialog at 100% width and height of the viewport, with appropriate transitions and behaviors aligned with Material Design principles.

#### References
- [Material Design Dialog component](https://m3.material.io/components/dialogs/overview)

### Use Case

- Complex forms
- Detail views with rich content or multiple sections
- Mobile-friendly interfaces
- Media viewers (images, videos, documents)
- Workflow wizards with complex steps
- Rich text editors
- Content creation interfaces
